Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: The mandatory daily pre-work safety briefing is starting in two minutes.
Story: I glance at my phone, my mother’s message lighting up the screen: “Don’t forget, today is the day for the family prayer. It’s important to us.” Her words echo in my mind, heavy with the weight of tradition. My family has always insisted that I honor our customs, especially now, when they feel our values are slipping away. But as I tuck my phone back into my pocket, the foreman’s voice booms across the site, calling everyone to the daily safety briefing. It’s non-negotiable—missing it means risking my job and letting down my crew. I can see my coworkers gathering, hard hats in hand, eyes expectant. My heart pounds as I stand between the pull of my family’s expectations and the demands of my job. I want to be the dutiful child, but I also need to be a reliable worker. The seconds tick by, and I feel the pressure mounting, torn between two worlds that both need me, both right now.
